summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: 11/25/1970: An unknown perpetrator placed a bomb in the men's restroom of the gymnasium at the University of California, Berkeley, United States. The bomb was discovered by a custodian and subsequently disarmed by a military bomb squad.
scite1: "Bomb Found at Berkeley," New York Times, November 27, 1970.

summary: 11/25/1970: Two days after the Armed Commandos of Liberation bombed the Consulate of the Dominican Republic, unknown perpetrators placed a bomb in the R.O.T.C. building of the University of Puerto Rico in San Juan, Puerto Rico. The fragmentation device was discovered and removed thirty minutes before it was set to detonate.
target1: R.O.T.C. building, University of Puerto Rico
addnotes: This incident took place two days after the a bombing of the Dominican Consulate in San Juan, Puerto Rico (197011230001).
scite1: "Independence Factions Believed Behind Puerto Rico's Recent Bombings," Washington Post, November 30, 1970.

summary: 12/1/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed Johnson Hall at the University of Oregon in Eugene, Oregon, United States. There were no casualties but the bomb caused $9,000 in damages.
weapdetail: Four to five sticks of dynamite
addnotes: The bomb was placed outside of a ground level window of Johnson Hall.  The building housed the office of the university president.
scite1: "Wind Shift Eases Oil Spill Threat," Washington Post, December 2, 1970.

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: 12/14/1970: Suspected members of the Armed Revolutionary Independence Movement (MIRA) firebombed the Headquarters of the Antipoverty Agency in Bridgeport, Connecticut, United States. There were no casualties but records involving the Spanish community and food intended for charity were destroyed.
weapdetail: Gasoline poured on porch set off by a firebomb
scite1: Lester A. Sobel, "Political Terrorism," Facts on File, Inc., 1975.

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: 12/15/1970: Unknown perpetrators firebombed three offices of the Army R.O.T.C. at the University of Connecticut in Storrs, Connecticut, United States. There were no casualties and the damages to the offices were modest. Some military records were lost.
target1: Army R.O.T.C. offices, University of Connecticut
weapdetail: Molotov cocktail gasoline in a bottle
addnotes: The fire was discovered at 1:45 AM.
scite1: U. of Connecticut Fire Bomb Target," New York Times, December 16, 1970.

summary: 12/16/1970: Unknown perpetrators threw two firebombs through the front window of a Selective Service office in Hollywood, Florida, United States. There were no casualties and the building sustained only minor damage.
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on D

summary: 12/18/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed a building that housed the draft board in San Mateo, California, United States. There were no casualties and it is unknown if the building was damaged.
target1: Building housing the draft board office in San Mateo California
motive: To protest and sabotage the draft
addnotes: A draft board office in San Mateo was firebombed three months later (197103150003).
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: 12/22/1970: A revolutionary leftist bombed National Guard trucks stationed at the Whitefish Bay Armory in Whitefish Bay, Wisconsin, United States. One truck was damaged but the resulting fire was extinguished before it had a chance to spread to the thirty other vehicles parked at the lot. There were many other bombings in the Milwaukee, Wisconsin area during this time period.
target1: Trucks at the Whitefish Bay Armory
motive: Protest the national guard and the US military
weapdetail: Four inch pipe bomb connected to a watch
addnotes: The bomb went off at 1:30 AM.  The perpetrator cut through a fence to sneak into the facilities.  The bomb was placed above the gas tank of the truck, but the tank did not explode.  However, some fuel did catch on fire.  This was one of many bombings and attempted bombings that took place in the Milwaukee Wisconsin area during a five month period. (197010280002, 197007220002, 197009040004, 197006290002, 197007000001, 197008050001, and 197007210004).
scite1: Alex P. Dobish, "Bay Bomb Suspect Leaves Footprints," Milwaukee Journal, December 22, 1970.

summary: 12/27/1970:  James Palmer Brewer and Randy Gerald Davis placed a bomb wrapped in a paper bag in front of the Army Recruiting Station in College Park, Georgia, United States. A janitor was injured picking up the bomb and glass windows and doors were shattered.
target1: Army Recruiting Station, College Park Georgia
motive: To protest and sabotage the US Military
weapdetail: Bomb consisted of around a quarter pound of black powder that was detonated by two batteries
addnotes: Six weeks later, James Palmer Brewer and Randy Gerald Davis bombed an Armed Forces Induction Center in Atlanta, Georgia (197102130001).  Brewer was a soldier who had gone  AWOL.  Luther Grier, a janitor, was burned and cut.
scite1: "Bomb Damages Ga. Recruiting Office," Washington Post, December 29, 1971.

summary: 12/31/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed the municipal court building in El Monte, California, United States. There were no casualties but a door of the building was destroyed and twelve windows were shattered.
target1: Municipal courthouse building in El Monte California
addnotes: There was a police station located fifty feet away from the courthouse.
scite1: "Bomb Damages Court Building," Washington Post, January 2, 1971.

summary: 1/1/1971: The Mount Gilead, North Carolina, United States garage of William Chambers, the father of civil rights attorney Julius Chambers, was suspected to have been destroyed by arson. There were no casualties  but the damages to building were estimated to be $11,000.
corp1: Garage of the father of a civil rights attorney
motive: To intimidate Julius Chambers from representing causes of the civil rights movement.
addnotes: There was a fire at the garage five months earlier that was not considered an arson attack.  This attack is linked with 197102040002.
scite1: "Arson Seen in 2nd NC Garage Fire," Afro-American, January 23, 1971.

summary: 1/5/1970: Unknown perpetrators threw a firebomb into an R.O.T.C. office at Claremont Men's College in Claremont, California, United States. There were no casualties but the building sustained an estimated $1,000 in damages.
addnotes: The sprinkler system in the building put out the flames.
scite1: "Firebomb Hits R.O.T.C. Room," Washington Post, January 6, 1971.

summary: 1/5/1971:  Unknown perpetrators bombed a military induction center in Oxnard, California, United States. There were no casualties and it is unknown if the center sustained damages.
motive: Protest the draft and the US military
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: 1/6/1971: Unknown perpetrators threw a firebomb into the Camp Fire Girls Headquarters in Pomona, California, United States. There were no casualties, however, the building was destroyed causing an estimated $50,000 in damages. This attack occurred during heightened racial tensions in Pomona which included an attempted boycott of the school system.
target1: Camp Fire Girls Headquarters in Pomona
motive: To protest the Pomona California school system
weapdetail: A firebomb was thrown through a window of the building.
addnotes: This attack took place during heightened racial tensions in Pomona, California.  Police believed that this attack might have been linked with racial disturbances (197101090001, 197101090002, and 197101110003) at Pomona High School where a  boycott by Black students was in the process of being implemented.
scite1: "Firebomb Causes $50,000 Damage," Washington Post, January 7, 1971.

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: 1/9/1971: Unknown perpetrators set a fire in the cafeteria at Garey High School in Pomona, California, United States. There were no casualties but the fire caused an estimated $15,000 in damages. This attack occurred during heightened racial tensions in Pomona which included an attempted boycott of the school system.
motive: To protest the Pomona California school system
addnotes: This attack took place during heightened racial tensions in Pomona, California.  At the time, Black students were in the process of implementing a boycott of the school system.  Police believed that this attack was connected with other racial disturbances in Pomona (197101060001, 197101090002, and 197101110003).  As a result of the attacks the schools closed down for a week.
scite1: "Pomona Tension Goes On," Los Angeles Sentinel, January 14, 1971.

summary: 1/9/1971:  Unknown perpetrators set a fire in the cafeteria at Hamilton Elementary School in Pomona, California, United States. There were no casualties and only minor damages were reported. This attack occurred during heightened racial tensions in Pomona which included an attempted boycott of the school system.
motive: To protest the Pomona California school system
addnotes: This attack took place during heightened racial tensions in Pomona, California.  At the time, Black students were in the process of implementing a boycott of the school system.  Police believed that this attack was connected with other racial disturbances in Pomona (197101060001, 197101090001, and 197101110003).  As a result of the attacks the schools closed down for a week.
scite1: "Pomona Tension Goes On," Los Angeles Sentinel, January 14, 1971.

summary: 1/11/1971: Unknown perpetrators set a fire in the cafeteria at Hamilton Elementary School in Pomona, California, United States. There were no injuries or fatalities and only minor damages were reported. This attack occurred during heightened racial tensions in Pomona which included an attempted boycott of the school system.
motive: To protest the Pomona California school system
weapdetail: Six separate fires were started in the cafeteria.
addnotes: This attack took place during heightened racial tensions in Pomona, California.  At the time, Black students were in the process of implementing a boycott of the school system.  Police believed that this attack was connected with other racial disturbances in Pomona (197101060001, 197101090001, and 197101090002).  As a result of the attacks the schools closed down for a week.
scite1: "Pomona Tension Goes On," Los Angeles Sentinel, January 14, 1971.

summary: 1/12/1971: Unknown perpetrators threw a Molotov cocktail through the front window of the Palos Verdes Peninsula Chamber of Commerce office in Rolling Hills Estates, California, United States. There were no casualties but damage to the chamber of commerce and two businesses housed in the same facility amounted to an estimated $12,000.
target1: Palos Verdes Peninsula Chamber of Commerce office, Rolling Hills Estates California
addnotes: The dry cleaning shop sustained smoke and water damage.
scite1: "Bulletin," Los Angeles Times, January 13, 1971.

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: 1/15/1971: In a series of related incidents, an unknown perpetrator bombed a Marine Recruiting Station located in the National Bronx Bank Building in the Bronx, New York, United States. Two people were injured and the bomb caused minor damage.
target1: Marine Recruiting Station housed in the National Bronx Bank Building
motive: To protest and sabotage the US Military
weapdetail: Pipe bomb placed in a shopping bag
addnotes: This is part of a multiple attack with 197101150005.  The bomb exploded at 11:00 AM.  The two people injured were Sgt. Leonard Godfrey and Pedro Torres.  Godfrey stated that he noticed a man place a shopping bag at the station which eventually blew up.
scite1: "2 Recruiting Stations Bombed in N.Y.," Washington Post, January 16, 1971.

summary: 1/15/1971: In a series of related incidents, unknown perpetrators bombed an Air Force Recruiting Station in Manhattan, New York, United States. There were no casualties and the bomb caused minor damage.
target1: Air Force Recruiting Station housed in a building in Harlem
motive: To protest and sabotage the US Military
addnotes: This is part of a multiple attack with 197101150004.  The bomb exploded at 11:40 AM.
scite1: "2 Recruiting Stations Bombed in N.Y.," Washington Post, January 16, 1971.

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: 1/19/1971: Unknown perpetrators bombed a Housing Authority Police Station in San Francisco, California, United States. There were no casualties but about thirty windows were shattered and power and communication lines were knocked out.
target1: Housing Authority Police Station, San Francisco
addnotes: The bomb was placed behind the police station and some believed that it might have been directed at the power and communication lines.  The police station was located in a predominately African American neighborhood.  Another bomb was discovered at a federal building in San Francisco two hours later (197101190002).
scite1: "Police Station Is Damaged By Bomb in San Francisco," Washington Post, January 21, 1971.

summary: 1/19/1971: Unknown perpetrators placed a time bomb adjacent to military recruiting offices housed in the old federal building at the San Francisco Civic Center in California, United States. The bomb was discovered and defused.
target1: Building housing the Army, Air Force, and Marine recruiting offices in San Francisco
addnotes: A Housing Authority Police Station in San Francisco was bombed two hours earlier (197101190001).
scite1: "Police Station Is Damaged By Bomb in San Francisco," Washington Post, January 21, 1971.

summary: 1/19/1971: Unknown perpetrators firebombed the home of James Ford in Cleveland, Ohio, United States. There were no casualties but Ford's home sustained $15,000 in damages. Ford was an administrator at the Cuyahoga Metropolitan Housing Authority. At the time, dissident employees of the organization were on strike.
corp1: Home of an official of the Cuyahoga Metropolitan Authority
motive: Protest the actions of the Cuyahoga Metropolitan Housing Authority
addnotes: James Ford was the assistant director of the Carvel Outhwaite public housing project.  Dissident employees were protesting the firing of the program's former housing director.
scite1: "Police Station Is Damaged By Bomb in San Francisco," Washington Post, January 21, 1971.

summary: 1/24/1971: At around 8:00 AM, a member of the Black Liberation Army flagged down a police officer driving his radio car in Manhattan, New York, United States. When the cop pulled over, the perpetrator began stabbing the officer with a knife. The officer then shot and killed the assailant. That morning, the New York Times received two anonymous calls stating that a New York policeman would be killed at 8:00 AM unless the BLA received $100,000.
addnotes: The police officer recovered from his stab wounds.  Josh Smith, a man purporting to be from the Black Liberation Army, called New York Channel 7 after the incident claiming that "no longer will the pig hatchet men plant their heels on our people."  He stated that the next two people to be targeted would be the commissioner and deputy commissioner of the New York Police Department.
scite1: Robert Daley, "Target Blue," Delacorte Press, 1973.

summary: 1/26/1971: Unknown perpetrators bombed the boiler room located at the north campus of Twin Lakes High School in West Palm Beach, Florida, United States. The explosion caused $10,000 in damages to the heating system. Twin Lakes High School was the scene of intense racial conflict.
target1: Boiler room at the north campus of Twin Lakes High School
motive: To protest the appointment of a White principal at a predominantly African American school
weapdetail: Dynamite connected to a clock device
addnotes: The bomb was similar to the device used in the attack on principal of Twin Lakes High School two weeks later (197102090002).  There were many instances of racial strife at the high school, and, two weeks before the incident, a white person was appointed principal of the district, despite the recommendations of a biracial committee.
scite1: "Timing Device Fails in Car Blast Attempt," Sarasota Herald-Tribune, February 10, 1971.

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: 2/4/1971: The Charlotte, North Carolina, United States law offices of civil rights attorney Julius Chambers were destroyed by arson. There were no casualties in the attack.
motive: To intimidate Julius Chambers from representing causes of the civil rights movement.
weapdetail: Investigators believed that the fire was set by a chemical.
addnotes: The NAACP pledged to assist Chambers rebuild his law offices.  This attack is linked with 197101010001.
scite1: "A Rights Office Burned in South," New York Times, November 5, 1971.

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: 2/9/1971: Unknown perpetrators placed a bomb underneath the car of Thomas H. Abbott, the principal of Twin Lakes High School in West Palm Beach, Florida, United States. The bomb failed to explode because the timing device of the weapon malfunctioned. Twin Lakes High School was the scene of intense racial conflict.
target1: Principal of Twin Lakes High School
motive: To protest the appointment of a White principal at a predominantly African American school
weapdetail: Six sticks of dynamite connected to a clock and a battery
addnotes: The bomb was similar to the device used in a bombing at Twin Lakes High School two weeks earlier (197101260001).  The car of the Palm Beach County's Superintendent was bombed three months later (197105120002).  There were many instances of racial strife at the high school, and, one month before the incident, a white person was appointed principal of the district, despite the recommendations of a biracial committee.  The bomb was set explode at 3:00 PM but the timing device malfunctioned.
scite1: "Timing Device Fails in Car Blast Attempt," Sarasota Herald-Tribune, February 10, 1971.

summary: 2/10/1971: Charles Lawrence, a member of a Neo-Nazi group, placed a dynamite bomb at the home of Ben Maidenburg in Akron, Ohio, United States. Maidenburg was the publisher of the Akron Beacon Journal. The bomb was discovered and subsequently removed.
motive: To protest the reporting of the Akron Beacon Journal
weapdetail: Four sticks of dynamite connected to a clock
addnotes: The bomb was set to detonate at 8:30 PM but was discovered four hours earlier.  Charles Lawrence was an organizer for the National Socialist White People's Party.  Ben Maidenburg's house was bombed seven months earlier by an unknown perpetrator (197007040004).
scite1: "Neo-Nazi Accused of Placing Bomb at Publisher's Home," New York Times, March 18, 1971.

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: 2/13/1971: James Palmer Brewer and Randy Gerald Davis bombed the Armed Forces Induction Center in Atlanta, Georgia, United States. There were no casualties but the blast shattered hundreds of windows.
motive: To protest and sabotage the US Military
addnotes: Six weeks earlier James Palmer Brewer and Randy Gerald Davis bombed an Army Recruiting Station in College Park, Georgia (197012270001).  Brewer was a soldier who had gone  AWOL.  The bomb was placed outside of the main doors of the building and detonated shortly before 5:00 AM.  The induction center was also the 81st Army Reserve Command Headquarters.
scite1: "Stanford Suspends Activist Professor," Washington Post, February 14, 1971.

summary: 2/14/1971: Five anti-war protesters broke into the Bucks County Selective Service office in Bristol, Pennsylvania, United States. The perpetrators set fire to draft records and ransacked the office. The interior of the office was heavily damaged and around half of the files were destroyed.
target1: Selective Service office Local Boards No. 35 and no. 335 in Bristol Pennsylvania
motive: To protest the War in Vietnam and the draft
weapdetail: Fire ignited with a flammable substance and files ransacked
addnotes: The perpetrators sawed there way into the office and the fire was ignited at 12:03 AM on February 15.  The perpetrators stated that they were influenced by the anti-war actions of Philip and Daniel Berrigan.
scite1: "National Can Co., Steel Union Settle," Washington Post, February 16, 1971.

summary: 2/16/1971: In a series of related incidents, Puerto Rican nationalists bombed El San Juan Hotel in San Juan, Puerto Rico. There were no casualties but the hotel sustained $5,500 in damages.
motive: To protest United States establishments in Puerto Rico
addnotes: This is part of multiple attack with 197102160002.  This might also be part of a multiple attack with the three other bombs and incendiary devices discovered at American establishments in Puerto Rico on the same day (197102160003, 197102160004, and 197102160005).  The bomb in this incident detonated near the hotel swimming pool.
scite1: "Tourists Flee Bomb Blasts in San Juan Hotels," Washington Post, February 18, 1971.

summary: 2/16/1971: In a series of related incidents, Puerto Rican nationalists bombed the Americana in San Juan, Puerto Rico. There were no casualties but the hotel sustained $5,000 in damages.
motive: To protest United States establishments in Puerto Rico
addnotes: This is part of multiple attack with 197102160001.  This might also be part of a multiple attack with the three other bombs and incendiary devices discovered at American establishments in Puerto Rico on the same day (197102160003, 197102160004, and 197102160005).  The bomb in this incident detonated near the hotel swimming pool.
scite1: "Tourists Flee Bomb Blasts in San Juan Hotels," Washington Post, February 18, 1971.

summary: 2/16/1971: In a series of five incidents that might have been related, Puerto Rican nationalists placed a pipe bomb at the United States Coast Guard radio beacon tower in San Juan, Puerto Rico. The bomb was discovered and deactivated two hours before it was set to detonate.
target1: United States Coast Guard radio beacon tower in San Juan Puerto Rico
motive: To protest United States presence in Puerto Rico
weapdetail: A timed pipe bomb was used in the attack.
scite1: "Tourists Flee Bomb Blasts in San Juan Hotels," Washington Post, February 18, 1971.

summary: 2/16/1971: In a series of five incidents that might have been related, Puerto Rican nationalists placed three Molotov cocktails in an office building housing American owned businesses in San Juan, Puerto Rico. The firebombs were discovered unignited and subsequently removed.
corp1: American owned business in Puerto Rico
target1: Office building housing American businesses in the Old City of San Juan
motive: To protest United States owned businesses in Puerto Rico
scite1: "Tourists Flee Bomb Blasts in San Juan Hotels," Washington Post, February 18, 1971.

summary: 2/16/1971: In a series of five incidents that might have been related, Puerto Rican nationalists placed an incendiary device in the Franklin's Store in Rio Piedras, Puerto Rico. The firebomb were discovered unignited and subsequently removed.
corp1: American owned business in Puerto Rico
motive: To protest United States owned businesses in Puerto Rico
addnotes: This might be part of a multiple attack with the four other bombings and attempted bombings of American establishments in Puerto Rico on the same day (197102160001, 197102160002, 197102160003, and 197102160004).  The incendiary device in this incident was discovered between clothing in the children's department of the store.
scite1: "Tourists Flee Bomb Blasts in San Juan Hotels," Washington Post, February 18, 1971.

summary: 2/20/1971: Miami Police Officer Victor Butler Jr. was ambushed by suspected members of the Black Afro-militant Movement (BAMM) in Miami, Florida, United States. The bullets struck him in the chest and back and he died instantly. BAMM members John Lane and John Murray Johnson were indicted of the murder but the charges were dropped when the police witness, and fellow BAMM member Jan Thurston, recanted his confession. Police eventually indicted Thurston for the murder but charges against him were also dropped because a judged ruled that he was questioned without probable cause.
motive: To promote violence against the establishment
addnotes: Victor Butler was an African American.  In his original confession, Thurston stated that he was in a car with 3-5 people that dropped Lane and Johnson off to commit the murder.  The Miami Police Department considers the case closed since Lane, Johnson, and Thurston, who the department believed to be involved in the incident, were arrested.
scite1: Dr. William Wilbanks, "Forgotten Heroes: Police Officers Killed in Dade County," Turner Publishing Company, 1996.

summary: 2/22/1970:  A realty office in Los Angeles, California, United States was bombed by the Chicano Liberation Front. Apparently the office was mistakenly thought to be owned by a critic of militant Chicanos. There were no casualties.
motive: To intimidate critics of the Chicano Liberation Front.
addnotes: The realty office that was bombed was apparently mistaken for an office that was owned by a critic of the Chicano Liberation Front.  On the outside of the wall of the office, "Chicano Liberation Front" was written with shoe polish.
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: 2/26/1971: Unknown perpetrators set fire to the R.O.T.C. building at the University of Hawaii, in Honolulu, United States. There were no casualties but the building sustained $70,000 in damages.
addnotes: A week later, another building on the University of Hawaii campus was set on fire, however, authorities did not believe that this incident was carried out by the same perpetrators (197103050001).
scite1: Lester A. Sobel, "Political Terrorism," Facts on File, Inc., 1975.

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: 2/27/1971: Unknown perpetrators placed a bomb in a Selective Service office in Rio Piedras, Puerto Rico. It is unknown if the bomb detonated.
motive: To protest the draft and United States presence in Puerto Rico
addnotes: Authorities suspected that the perpetrators of this incident might have participated in campus riots at the University of Puerto Rico two weeks later.
scite1: Martin Arnold, "San Juan Rioting and Bomb Studied," New York Times, March 16, 1971.

summary: 3/5/1971: Unknown perpetrators set a travel industry management school building on fire at the University of Hawaii in Honolulu, United States. There were no casualties but the building sustained an estimated $7,500 in damages.
target1: Travel industry management school building, University of Hawaii
weapdetail: Fire caused by gasoline splashed around the building
addnotes: A week earlier, the R.O.T.C. building at the University of Hawaii campus was destroyed by fire, however, authorities did not believe that this incident was carried out by the same perpetrators (197102260002).  A broken bottleneck with a wick and matchbook were discovered at the scene.
scite1: Lester A. Sobel, "Political Terrorism," Facts on File, Inc., 1975.

summary: 3/6/1971: In a series of related events, unknown perpetrators firebombed the predominantly Black Mount Orange Baptist Church in Texarkana, Texas, United States. There were no casualties but the Church was completely destroyed.
motive: Two different motives suspected.  Either Black radicals punishing the Churches for not allowing expelled Black students to temporarily use their facilities for classes or White racists trying to intimidate the African American community of Texarkana Texas.
addnotes: Part of a multiple attack with 197103060002, 197103070001, and 197103070002. This incident took place during heightened racial tensions in Texarkana Texas after a large fight between Black and White students.  Leaders of the Black community were unsure whether the attack was carried out by White Racists or Black radicals.  Many Blacks were disappointed that the Churches did not open up their facilities for the 126 Black students expelled as a result of the fight.  Black officials were afraid to speculate the identities of the perpetrators because they feared more reprisals.
scite1: Homar Bigart, "Burned Churches Rebuilt in Texas," New York Times, June 21, 1972.

summary: 3/6/1971: In a series of related events, unknown perpetrators firebombed the predominantly Black St. Paul's Baptist Church in Texarkana, Texas, United States. There were no casualties but the Church was completely destroyed.
motive: Two different motives suspected.  Either Black radicals punishing the Churches for not allowing expelled Black students to temporarily use their facilities for classes or White racists trying to intimidate the African American community of Texarkana Texas.
addnotes: Part of a multiple attack with 197103060001, 197103070001, and 197103070002.This incident took place during heightened racial tensions in Texarkana Texas after a large fight between Black and White students.  Leaders of the Black community were unsure whether the attack was carried out by White Racists or Black radicals.  Many Blacks were disappointed that the Churches did not open up their facilities for the 126 Black students expelled as a result of the fight.  Black officials were afraid to speculate the identities of the perpetrators because they feared more reprisals.
scite1: Homar Bigart, "Burned Churches Rebuilt in Texas," New York Times, June 21, 1972.

summary: 3/7/1971: In a series of related events, unknown perpetrators attempted to firebomb the predominantly Black New Town Church in Texarkana, Texas, United States. The firebomb malfunctioned and the church sustained no damages.
motive: Two different motives suspected.  Either Black radicals punishing the Churches for not allowing expelled Black students to temporarily use their facilities for classes or White racists trying to intimidate the African American community of Texarkana Texas.
weapdetail: The firebomb sputtered but failed to explode
addnotes: Part of a multiple attack with 197103060001, 197103060002,and 197103070002. This incident took place during heightened racial tensions in Texarkana Texas after a large fight between Black and White students.  Leaders of the Black community were unsure whether the attack was carried out by White Racists or Black radicals.  Many Blacks were disappointed that the Churches did not open up their facilities for the 126 Black students expelled as a result of the fight.  Black officials were afraid to speculate the identities of the perpetrators because they feared more reprisals.
scite1: Homar Bigart, "Burned Churches Rebuilt in Texas," New York Times, June 21, 1972.

summary: 3/7/1971: In a series of related events, unknown perpetrators firebombed the predominantly Black Holy Chapel church in Texarkana, Texas, United States. There were no casualties and the church sustained minor damages.
motive: Two different motives suspected.   Either Black radicals punishing the Churches for not allowing expelled Black students to temporarily use their facilities for classes or White racists trying to intimidate the African American community of Texarkana Texas.
addnotes: Part of a multiple attack with 197103060001, 197103060002, and 197103070001. This incident took place during heightened racial tensions in Texarkana Texas after a large fight between Black and White students.  Leaders of the Black community were unsure whether the attack was carried out by White Racists or Black radicals.  Many Blacks were disappointed that the Churches did not open up their facilities for the 126 Black students expelled as a result of the fight.  Black officials were afraid to speculate the identities of the perpetrators because they feared more reprisals.
scite1: Homar Bigart, "Burned Churches Rebuilt in Texas," New York Times, June 21, 1972.

summary: 3/11/1973: Members of the Ku Klux Klan were suspected of bombing the Socialist Worker Party headquarters in Houston, Texas, United States. There were no casualties but the building sustained around $2,500 in damages.
target1: Harris County headquarters of the Socialist Workers Party
addnotes: Of the four perpetrators indicted, two of them, Beam and Moratto, were Klansmen.  Hutto was also accused of being a member of the Klan.  The perpetrators were also indicted for 197005120002 and 197010090001.
scite1: Martin Waldron, "2 Bombings Laid to 4 in Houston," New York Times, June 12, 1971.

summary: 3/12/1971: Unknown perpetrators bombed the Portland Police Community Relations Center in Portland, Oregon, United States. There were no casualties but the building sustained $10,000 in damages.
addnotes: The bomb detonated in the early morning.
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on D

summary: 3/15/1971: Unknown perpetrators firebombed a draft board office in San Mateo, California, United States. There were no casualties and it is unknown if the office was damaged.
target1: Draft board office, San Mateo California
motive: To protest and sabotage the draft
addnotes: The San Mateo draft board was bombed three months earlier (197012180001).
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: 3/17/1971: Unknown perpetrators set fire to a classroom used by the Air Force R.O.T.C. at Cornell University in Ithaca, New York, United States. There were no casualties and the fire caused only minor damage.
target1: Air Force R.O.T.C. classroom in Barton Hall at Cornell University
weapdetail: Chairs, cloth, paper in a pile and lit on fire
addnotes: On the chalk board of the classroom, the Young Americans for Freedom, claimed responsibility for the attack.  Authorities did not take this claim seriously as the YAF was a very conservative organization and it did not have a chapter at Cornell University.
scite1: "Fire in R.O.T.C. Classroom At Cornell Called Deliberate," New York Times, March 18, 1971.

summary: 3/18/1971: Unknown perpetrators bombed an Army Recruiting office in Jacksonville, Florida, United States. There were no casualties and it is unknown if the office was damaged.
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: 3/19/1971: Suspected members of the Armed Revolutionary Independence Movement (MIRA) set off three incendiaries at the B. Altman Department Store in Manhattan, New York, United States. There were no casualties and the store sustained $50 in damages.
weapdetail: There were three incendiary devices that were cigarette packs containing chemicals, batteries, and watch wires.
addnotes: Eduardo Cruz and Wilfredo were suspected members of MIRA.
scite1: Juan M. Vasquez "Bomb Goes Off in Alman's Here; Suspects Tied to 100 Other Plots," New York Times, March 20, 1971.

summary: 3/21/1971: Unknown perpetrators threw a Molotov cocktail into the Dean's office at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University in Medford, Massachusetts, United States. There were no casualties but the office of the Dean and an adjoining office were destroyed and two other offices were damaged. Total damages amounted to $75,000.
corp1: Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University
target1: Dean of the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy
motive: To protest Tufts University's alleged association with the Central Intelligence Agency and Dean Gullion's policies towards the War in Vietnam
weapdetail: Molotov cocktail consisting of a bi-chemical mixture
addnotes: The firebomb went off at 4:41 AM.  The Fletcher School had received threats five months before the incident.  The Students for a Democratic Society had routinely protested the university's alleged association for the CIA, but denied any involvement in the firebombing.
scite1: "Blaze Destroys Offices At Tufts," New York Times, March 22, 1971.

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: 3/23/1971: Unknown perpetrators detonated two small bombs at in the Center Building at Wayne State University in Detroit, Michigan, United States. There were no casualties but the buildings sustained around $4,000 in damages.
addnotes: Officially, it was estimated that the plumbing of the building sustained between $3,000-$5,000 in damages.
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on D

summary: 3/23/1971: Unknown perpetrators firebombed the Mountclef Bank of America branch on the campus of California Lutheran College in Thousand Oaks, California, United States. There were no casualties but the building sustained an estimated $20,000 in damages.
target1: Mountclef branch of Bank of America, Thousand Oaks California
motive: Bank of America was perceived to symbolize the "capitalist exploitation of the little man."
addnotes: Hours before the incident, a Bank of America branch was bombed in Mill Valley California (197103230001).  The bank opened on time as only the conference room was damaged.  The word "escape" was discovered on a wall of the building.
scite1: "Southland: Campus Bank Opens Despite Fire Bombing," Los Angeles Times,, March 25, 1971.

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: 3/30/1971: The Jewish Defense League is suspected of planting a pipe bomb in front of a building that housed the headquarters of the Communist Party USA in Manhattan, New York, United States. There were no casualties but the front door of the building was damaged and windows at surrounding buildings were shattered.
target1: Communist Party USA, New York Headquarters
motive: To protest the treatment of Jews by the Soviet Union
addnotes: The Associated Press received a predawn phone call from an unknown person announcing that there would be a bombing at the building.  The Jewish Defense League denied involvement in the incident.  Later in the day, the Students Activists for Soviet Jewry, a front for the JDL, demonstrated in front of the building.  The bombing coincided with the opening of the congress of the Communist Party in Moscow which was attended by delegates of the American Communist Party.
scite1: "Militants Communists Protest," Sarasota Journal, March 30, 1971.

summary: 3/31/1971: Unknown perpetrators firebombed a Military Recruiting Station in Denver, Colorado, United States. There were no casualties and it is unknown if the center sustained any damages.
addnotes: The station focused on recruiting minorities into the United States military.
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: 4/2/1971: Police Officers Leonard A. Christiansen and Paul C. Teel were ambushed while on duty in Riverside, California, United States. The officers, responding to a fake burglary call, were shot and killed as they got out of their car. Police believed that the attack was carried out by three Black militants.
addnotes: Officer Christiansen was killed instantly, while Officer Teel survived long enough to call for help, but died on his way to the hospital.  This incident took place during racial tension in Riverside California.  Three African Americans; Civil Rights leader Gary Lawton, Nehemiah Jackson and Larrie Gardner, were tried three times for the murders, but were never convicted.
scite1: Jon R. Waltz, "Beneath the Wheels of Justice; The Ambush Murders," Washington Post, November 25, 1979.

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: 4/3/1971: Dr. R. Wiley Brownlee, high school principle and promoter of racial coexistence was struck down and kidnapped by members of the Ku Klux Klan in Ypsilanti, Michigan, United States. Dr. Brownlee was released later in the night but not before he was tarred and feathered.
motive: Intimidate people who promote racial harmony
weapdetail: The shotguns were not fired.  The target was struck down either with the shotgun or by fist.
addnotes: The length of the kidnapping was estimated to be two hours.  In response to the attack, Dr. Brownlee jokingly stated that it made him the Blackest man in town.  Robert Miles, the leader of Michigan's KKK, and four others were indicted for the attack.  Robert Miles was convicted.  He was also convicted for incident 197108300002.
scite1: "High School Principal 'Tarred and Feathered,'" Atlanta Daily World, April 4, 1971.

summary: 4/3/1971: Unknown perpetrators mistakenly threw two Molotov cocktails into an office next door to the Worth County Selective Service office in Sylvester, Georgia, United States. There were no casualties but the firebomb caused $8,000 in damage.
target1: Worth County Selective Service Office, Sylvester Georgia
addnotes: The police were confident that the firebomb was intended for the Selective Service office.
scite1: "Georgia News Briefs," Rome News-Tribune, April 6, 1971.

summary: 4/5/1971: Unknown perpetrators bombed the Bank of America branch in Ben Lomond, California, United States. There were no casualties but the building sustained minor damages.
target1: Bank of America, Ben Lomond California
motive: Bank of America was perceived to symbolize the "capitalist exploitation of the little man."
weapdetail: Two six-inch pipe bombs containing black powder taped together
addnotes: The same Bank of America branch was firebombed in July (197107280002).
scite1: "Bank Bombed in California," New York Times, April 6, 1971.

summary: 4/5/1971: In a series of related attacks, unknown perpetrators firebombed a pharmacy and cafeteria that was owned by a member of the Puerto Rican Independence movement in San Juan, Puerto Rico. There were no casualties but the property sustained more than $100,000 in damages.
corp1: Business owned by member of the Puerto Rican Independence movement
motive: To protest members of the Puerto Rican Independence movement
addnotes: This is part of a multiple attack with 197104050003.  The owner of the business was a member of the Movimiento Indpendencia.
scite1: "Puerto Rico Firms Firebombed," Washington Post, April 6, 1971.

summary: 4/5/1971: In a series of related attacks, unknown perpetrators firebombed a bookstore that was owned by a member of the Puerto Rican Independence movement in San Juan, Puerto Rico. There were no casualties but the building sustained heavy damage.
corp1: Business owned by member of the Puerto Rican Independence movement
motive: To protest members of the Puerto Rican Independence movement
addnotes: This is part of a multiple attack with 197104050002.  The owner of the business was a member of the Movimiento Indpendencia.
scite1: "Puerto Rico Firms Firebombed," Washington Post, April 6, 1971.

summary: 4/8/1971: The Fresno County Courthouse was bombed in Fresno, California, United States. There were no casualties and the building sustained only minor damage. Authorities were unsure who committed the attack, but minutes after the explosion, police received a phone call stating that "there's a bomb at the Chicano Liberation Front."
addnotes: The bomb detonated around 9:30 AM. Three weeks later, an Armed Forces Induction Center in Fresno, California was bombed (197104200001).
scite1: "Explosion Rips Fresno Courthouse," Washington Post, April 9, 1971.

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: 4/14/1971: Two unknown perpetrators threw three Molotov cocktails at the Campus Police Headquarters of Stanford University in Palo Alto, California, United States. Only one of the three firebombs exploded causing little damage.
addnotes: Two youths were witnessed throwing the Molotov cocktails.  At the time, there were two major controversies on the Stanford University campus.  One was the firing of an African American janitor at the University.  The other was a police search of the offices of the Stanford Daily, a campus newspaper.  Nine days later, the office of the President of Stanford University was bombed (197104230002).
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on D

summary: 4/14/1971: Puerto Rican nationalists placed a bomb at the Caribe Hilton Hotel in San Juan, Puerto Rico. The bomb was discovered and subsequently dismantled.
motive: To protest United States establishments in Puerto Rico
scite1: "Catholics Closing 56 Schools," Washington Post, April 19, 1971.

summary: 4/15/1971: Unknown perpetrators bombed a Selective Service office in Los Angeles, California, United States. There were no casualties and it is unknown if the office was damaged.
motive: To protest and sabotage the draft
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: 4/19/1971: The Armed Commandos of Liberation claimed responsibility for detonating two bombs in American owned businesses at the El Comandante Shopping Center in San Juan, Puerto Rico. The bombs caused extensive damage and three people were injured by flying glass.
corp1: American owned business in Puerto Rico
target1: Franklin's Women's Apparel store and Thom McCan shoe store, San Juan Puerto Rico
motive: To protest United States owned businesses in Puerto Rico
addnotes: The bombs were placed in a Thom McCan shoe store and Franklin's Women's Apparel store.  Furthermore, other United States establishments such as Woolworth's, CIT Finance Company, and Burger King were damaged in the incident.
scite1: "Catholics Closing 56 Schools," Washington Post, April 19, 1971.

summary: 4/20/1971: Unknown perpetrators bombed the Fresno Armed Forces Examining and Induction Center in Fresno, California, United States. There were no casualties but the exterior of the building sustained minor damage.
target1: Armed Forces Examining and Induction Center
motive: To protest and sabotage the US Military
addnotes: The bomb detonated around 11:20 PM.  A courthouse in Fresno California was bombed three weeks earlier (197104080001).  Moreover, the same induction center was previously bombed on November 1, 1970 (197011010003).
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on D

summary: 4/20/1971: For the second time in six weeks, unknown perpetrators bombed a Bank of America branch in Berkeley, California, United States. There were no casualties but windows were shattered at the bank and at a business across the street.
target1: Bank of America, South Berkeley California
motive: Bank of America was perceived to symbolize the "capitalist exploitation of the little man."
addnotes: Six weeks earlier, the same Bank of America branch was bombed (197103030002).  The bomb detonated at 3:31 AM.  The device was placed in front of the bank.
scite1: "Bank of America Bombed," New York Times, April 21, 1971.

summary: 4/20/1971: Unknown perpetrators firebombed a Selective Service office in Richfield, Minnesota, United States. There were no casualties and it is unknown if the office was damaged.
motive: To protest and sabotage the draft
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: 4/23/1971: Suspected revolutionary leftists firebombed two delivery trucks parked outside of the main post office in Los Gatos, California, United States. There were no casualties but the trucks were damaged.
target1: Main Post Office, Los Gatos California
weapdetail: Wine bottles filled with gasoline ignited on the hoods of the two vehicles
addnotes: One week later, ten trucks parked at the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, located four blocks away from the post office, were set on fire (197104290004).  Authorities stated that this incident was not related to the bombing at Stanford University on the same day (197104230002).  There were three other bombings in Northern California on April 23rd (197104230001, 197104230004, and 197104230005).
scite1: "California Blasts Damage College, Bank, Parole Unit," Baltimore Sun, 4/24/1971.

summary: 4/23/1971: A suspected member of the Weathermen bombed a Bank of America branch in Mill Valley, California, United States for the second time in a month. There were no casualties but the night depositary box was damaged and a window was shattered.
target1: Bank of America, Mill Valley California
motive: Bank of America was perceived to symbolize the "capitalist exploitation of the little man."
addnotes: After the bomb went off, a caller phoned the police station and claimed credit for the incident on behalf of the Weathermen.  Bruce Paul Lohmann admitted carrying out this incident and the bombing of a different Bank of America in Mill Valley on March 23rd and Tamalpais High School on April 27th (197103230001 and 197104230004).  It is unknown if he was actually a member of the Weathermen.  The bomb detonated at 8:04 AM.  There were four other bombings in Northern California on April 23rd (197104230001, 197104230002,197104230003, and 197104230005).
scite1: "California Blasts Damage College, Bank, Parole Unit," Baltimore Sun, 4/24/1971.

summary: 4/23/1971: Unknown perpetrators shot two electrical transformers that provided power to Stanford University in Palo Alto, California, United States. There were no casualties but the transformers were damaged.
corp1: Central power station for Stanford University
target1: Two electric transformers at the central power station for Stanford University
weapdetail: Four shots from either a rifle or pistol
addnotes: It is unknown if the damage to the electric transformers caused the power to go out at Stanford University.  This might be part of a multiple attack with the bombing at Stanford University later in the day (197104230002).  There were three other bombings in Northern California on April 23rd (197104230001, 197104230003, and 197104230004).
scite1: "California Blasts Damage College, Bank, Parole Unit," Baltimore Sun, 4/24/1971.

summary: 4/24/1971: There was a suspected bombing of the Army National Guard Armory in Youngstown, Ohio, United States. There were no casualties and it is unknown if the building sustained any damages.
target1: Army National Guard Armory, Youngstown Ohio
motive: To protest and the National Guard
addnotes: The incident occurred at 1:23 AM.  There are conflicting reports as to whether the authorities believed that this was an accidental explosion within the National Guard facilities or if it was intentionally bombed.
scite1: "Blast Rips Armory in Ohio City," Chicago Tribune, April 24, 1971.

summary: 4/25/1971: In a series of related incidents, unknown perpetrators threw a Molotov cocktail into Bauer Hall at Claremont Men's College in Claremont, California, United States. R.O.T.C. classes were taught in the building. The firebomb caused only slight damage.
target1: Building housing R.O.T.C. classrooms, Claremont Men's College
addnotes: This is part of a multiple attack with 197104250002.  The Molotov cocktail was thrown around 12:30 AM.  It was suspected that the fire failed to spread throughout the building because it was raining at the time.  The next day, the president's office at Harvey Mudd College in Claremont California was firebombed (197104260001).
scite1: "Southland: Quake Aftershock Rocks Valley," Los Angeles Times,, April 26, 1971.

summary: 4/25/1971: In a series of related incidents, unknown perpetrators threw a Molotov cocktail into Sumner Hall at Pomona College in Claremont, California, United States. The firebomb caused only slight damage to the building.
addnotes: This is part of a multiple attack with 197104250001.  The Molotov cocktail was thrown around 3:30 AM.  It was suspected that the fire failed to spread throughout the building because it was raining at the time.  The next day, the president's office at Harvey Mudd College in Claremont California was firebombed (197104260001).
scite1: "Southland: Quake Aftershock Rocks Valley," Los Angeles Times,, April 26, 1971.

summary: 4/26/1971: Unknown perpetrators firebombed the President's office of Harvey Mudd College in Claremont, California, United. There were no casualties and it not known if the office was damaged in the incident.
target1: Office of the President of Harvey Mudd College
addnotes: One day before the incident, there were two firebombings at colleges in Claremont California (197104250001 and 197104250002).
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: 4/27/1971: A bomb detonated in a men's restroom at Tamalpais High School in Mill Valley, California, United States. There were no casualties but the restroom was damaged. Two days after the bombing, Bruce Paul Lohmann, a student at the school, was arrested and admitted carrying out this attack as well as two other recent bombings at banks in the area.
target1: Men's Restroom of Tamalpais High School
addnotes: Bruce Paul Lohmann was a student at Tamalpais High School.  Lohmann also admitted bombing two Bank of America branches in  Mill Valley California (197103230001 and 197104230004).  There were two other fires set at the high school during the same week and there was a bomb threat against the school while Lohmann was being questioned.
scite1: "Ohio Governor Pleads For May Day Restraint," Washington Post, April 30, 1971.

summary: 4/27/1971: Unknown perpetrators bombed Julien's Furniture Store in Los Angeles, California, United States. There were no casualties but the store was damaged.
weapdetail: Bomb consisting of low-grade black powder
addnotes: Authorities suspected that this incident might be connected with the bombing of a Bank of America in Los Angeles a day later (197104280002).  Both incidents used bombs consisting of similar material.
scite1: Robert Watich, "Three-Way Probe Seeks Possible Link in L.A. Bombings," Los Angeles Times, May 1, 1971.

summary: 4/28/1971: Unknown perpetrators detonated a pipe bomb outside of the Bank of America branch at the Kaiser Center in Oakland, California, United States. There were no casualties but the building sustained an estimated $8,500 in damages.
target1: Bank of America, Kaiser Center branch in Oakland California
motive: Bank of America was perceived to symbolize the "capitalist exploitation of the little man."
weapdetail: Nine-inch long, three-inch diameter pipe bomb
addnotes: Two young men were seen "hurriedly leaving the scene."  The bomb detonated around 5:00 AM.
scite1: "Bomb Explodes at Bank," New York Times, April 29, 1971.

summary: 4/28/1971: Suspected members of the Chicano Liberation Front bombed a Lincoln Heights Bank of America branch in Los Angeles, California, United States. There were no casualties but the bank was damaged.
target1: Lincoln Heights branch of Bank of America, Los Angeles
motive: Bank of America was perceived to symbolize the "capitalist exploitation of the little man."
weapdetail: Bomb consisting of low-grade black powder
addnotes: Authorities suspected that this incident might be connected with the bombing of a furniture store in Los Angeles a day earlier (197104270002).  Both incidents used bombs consisting of similar substances.  The Chicano Liberation Front claimed credit for the incident in a tape recording sent to the Los Angeles Free Press.  The CLF stated that they were "fed up with our people being treated like dogs." However, authorities could not confirm if the CLF actually committed the attack.
scite1: Robert Watich, "Three-Way Probe Seeks Possible Link in L.A. Bombings," Los Angeles Times, May 1, 1971.

summary: 4/29/1971: In a series of two incidents that might have been part of a multiple attack, suspected members of the Chicano Liberation Front bombed a Safeway in Los Angeles, California, United States. There were no casualties but a hole was torn into the roof of the building.
motive: To protest the treatment of Mexican-Americans
weapdetail: Small black powder device thrown at the building
addnotes: This might be part of a multiple attack with the bombing of the Bank of America in Los Angeles less than an hour later (197104290003).  Both incidents took place in the East Los Angeles area and used similar types of bombs.  The Chicano Liberation Front claimed credit for the incident in a tape recording sent to the Los Angeles Free Press.  The CLF stated that they were "fed up with our people being treated like dogs." However, authorities could not confirm if the CLF actually committed the attack.
scite1: "Bank, Store Bombed, Trucks Burned in L. A.," Washington Post, May 1, 1971.

summary: 4/29/1971: In a series of two incidents that might have been part of a multiple attack, suspected members of the Chicano Liberation Front bombed a Bank of America branch in Los Angeles, California, United States. There were no casualties but the building sustained $1,600 in damages.
target1: Bank of America, Montebello branch in Los Angeles
motive: Bank of America was perceived to symbolize the "capitalist exploitation of the little man."
weapdetail: Black powder device tossed from a car at the building
addnotes: This might be part of a multiple attack with the bombing of Safeway in Los Angeles less than an hour earlier (197104290002).  Both incidents took place in the East Los Angeles area and used similar types of bombs.  The bomb was thrown from a car located in an alley behind the building.  The Chicano Liberation Front claimed credit for the incident in a tape recording sent to the Los Angeles Free Press.  The CLF stated that they were "fed up with our people being treated like dogs." However, authorities could not confirm if the CLF actually committed the attack.
scite1: "Bank, Store Bombed, Trucks Burned in L. A.," Washington Post, May 1, 1971.

summary: 4/29/1971: Suspected revolutionary leftists set fire to ten trucks belonging to the Pacific Gas and Electric Company in Los Gatos, California, United States. All ten trucks were destroyed.
target1: Trucks belonging to the Pacific Gas and Electric Company in Los Gatos California
addnotes: A week earlier delivery trucks parked at a Los Gatos post office, located four blocks away from the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, were firebombed (197104230003).
scite1: "New Bombings Noted," The Bulletin, April 30, 1971.

summary: 4/29/1971: Christopher Brian Cowsar went to the Air Force Recruiting Station in Berkeley, California, United States and stabbed Air Force Sergeant Rogers S. Mobley to death. During the incident Cowsar screamed, "he's sending people to Vietnam. He's got to die."
target1: Air Force Recruiting Sergeant in Berkeley California
motive: To protest the War in Vietnam and the draft
addnotes: Christopher Brian Cowsar was a former marine.  He was captured by two men who rushed to save Sergeant Mobley after they heard him screaming.
scite1: "Bank, Store Bombed, Trucks Burned in L. A.," Washington Post, May 1, 1971.

summary: 4/30/1971: Unknown perpetrators broke into the National Guard Armory in San Jose, California, United States and set fire to trucks stationed in the parking lot. Three vehicles were destroyed, three vehicles were heavily damaged, and one trailer was slightly damaged. Total losses were estimated at $20,000.
target1: Trucks stationed at the National Guard Armory in San Jose California
motive: To protest and sabotage the National Guard
weapdetail: Gasoline drained from the parked trucks and set on fire
addnotes: The perpetrators entered into the armory by cutting a hole through a surrounding fence.  Sixty-nine other trucks stationed in the parking lot were not damaged.
scite1: "Bank, Store Bombed, Trucks Burned in L. A.," Washington Post, May 1, 1971.

summary: 4/30/1971: Unknown perpetrators failed in their attempts to bomb the Selective Service office in Braintree, Massachusetts, United States.
motive: To protest and sabotage the draft
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: 5/4/1971: Unknown perpetrators attempted to firebomb an Air Force Recruiting Station in Chico, California, United States. However, the bomb fizzled out before it was able to ignite.
target1: Air Force Recruiting Station, Chico California
motive: To protest the War in Vietnam and the draft
addnotes: Hours after this incident, a bomb was detonated at a Bank of America branch in Chico California (197105050003).  A day later, a bookstore in Chico California was firebombed (197105050004).
scite1: "Power Station, Refinery Bombed on Coast," Baltimore Sun, May 7. 1971.

summary: 5/4/1971: Unknown perpetrators bombed the transmission towers of the KMAK radio station in Fresno, California, United States. A junction box was damaged and the station was temporarily knocked off the air.
weapdetail: Sticks of dynamite tossed over a fence
addnotes: KMAK was a country and western music station.
scite1: "Fresno Radio Station Cut Off by Bombing," The Milwaukee Journal, May 5, 1971.

summary: 5/4/1971: Two radical leftists failed in their attempts to firebomb a Bank of America branch in San Bruno, California, United States.
target1: Bank of America, San Bruno California
motive: To communicate to the general public that 'political activities' are not just limited to extremist groups
addnotes: In addition to George Patterson, an unarmed 17 year old male was also arrested.  Weeks later, the perpetrators  attempted to firebomb the San Bruno Herald (197105210002).  The perpetrators stated that they just wanted to get their message out and did not want to cause any damage.  They added that they did not belong to any 'fringe political group.'
scite1: "Tried to Communicate, Bombing Suspect Says," Los Angeles Times,, May 21, 1971.

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: 5/5/1971: Unknown perpetrators threw a firebomb at the American Opinion Bookstore in Chico, California, United States. The firebomb failed to break through the window of the store but scorched the outside wall of the building.
addnotes: Several hours before this incident, a Bank of America branch in Chico, California was bombed (197105050003).  The day before the incident there was an attempted firebombing against the Armed Forces Recruiting Station in Chico (197105040003).
scite1: "Bombs Hit California Businesses," Sarasota Herald-Tribune, May 6, 1971.

summary: 5/5/1971: Unknown perpetrators threw three firebombs into the Old Main building at Arizona State University in Tempe, United States. The fires were extinguished before any damage was inflicted on the building.
target1: Old Main building, Arizona State University
motive: Suspected motive is to protest against the Vietnam War
addnotes: The incident took place a day after the one year anniversary of the Kent State shootings.  On May 5, 1971, there were protests against the Vietnam War held all over the country.
scite1: "Thousands Rally Against War," Washington Post, May 6, 1971.

summary: 5/5/1971: Unknown perpetrators firebombed a Selective Service office that was located in a Federal building in Kansas City, Kansas, United States. There were no casualties and it is not known if the building sustained any damages.
target1: Selective Service office housed in a Federal building in Kansas City Kansas
motive: To protest and sabotage the draft
addnotes: The firebomb was suspected of being a Molotov cocktail.
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: 5/5/1971: Unknown perpetrators placed a pipe bomb on a street in the vicinity the campus of the University of California, Riverside, United States. The bomb was discovered and subsequently removed.
weapdetail: Pipe bomb connected to a timing device
addnotes: It is unknown when the bomb was supposed to detonate.  It is believed that the timing mechanism of the device was damaged when the bomb was dropped from a moving vehicle.
scite1: "Fresno Radio Station, Bank at Chino Bombed," Los Angeles Times, May 6, 1971.

summary: 5/6/1971: Unknown perpetrators bombed an unmanned Pacific Gas & Electric Company substation in the vicinity of San Jose, California, United States. A power generator was knocked out and electric service was temporarily stopped to Los Altos, Lost Gatos, Davenport, and Big Basin.
target1: Pacific Gas & Electric Company Substation, ten miles west of San Jose
addnotes: Possibly part of a multiple attack with 197105060004.  Both attacks were against energy targets in California at around the same time.  However, there were many bombings in California during this time period.  Also, the explosives used in the two attacks were not the same.  Extent of damages coded as unknown because it could not be determined the cost of the power outage to the four Californian cities.
scite1: "Power Station, Refinery Bombed on Coast," Baltimore Sun, May 7. 1971.

summary: 5/6/1971: Suspected members of the Chicano Liberation Front bombed a Standard Oil refinery in East Los Angeles, California, United States. Standard Oil was the target of anti-war demonstrators later that day. There were no casualties but the attack caused an estimated $5,000 in damages.
target1: Standard Oil of California refinery in East Los Angeles
motive: To protest the Vietnam War or to protest the treatment of Mexican-Americans
weapdetail: Bomb apparently consisting of sticks of dynamite
addnotes: Possibly part of a multiple attack with 197105060003.  Both attacks were against energy targets in California at around the same time.  However, there were many bombings in California during this time period.  Also, the explosives used in the two attacks were not the same.  The offices of standard oil were the targets of anti-war protesters the same day as the bombing.  Standard Oil of California was also known as the Chevron Oil Company.  Moreover, the Chicano Liberation Army claimed credit for the incident in a tape recording sent to the Los Angeles Free Press.  The CLF stated that they were "fed up with our people being treated like dogs." However, authorities could not confirm if the CLF actually committed the attack.
scite1: "Power Station, Refinery Bombed on Coast," Baltimore Sun, May 7. 1971.

summary: 5/6/1971: Unknown perpetrators firebombed a Military Recruiting Center in Burlingame, California, United States. It is unknown if the recruiting center sustained any damages.
scite1: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: 5/6/1971: An explosive device detonated within the vicinity of Military Trucks at the Naval Ammunition Depot in Hawthorne, Nevada, United States. Private Charles Henderson was killed and Lance Corporal Charles Bauer was injured.
target1: Military Trucks at Naval Ammunition Depot in Hawthorne Nevada
motive: To protest and sabotage the US Military
addnotes: There are conflicting reports as to whether authorities believed that the explosive device was set off intentionally due to sabotage or if the incident was accidental.
scite1: "The Nation: 16 Detroit Police Seized in Gambling Drive," Los Angeles Times,, May 7, 1971.

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: 5/8/1971: Suspected members of the Chicano Liberation Front bombed the Los Angeles County welfare office located in the Department of Public Social Services Building in Los Angeles, California, United States. The were no casualties but the front door was destroyed.
motive: To protest the treatment of Mexican-Americans
addnotes: The Chicano Liberation Front claimed credit for the incident in a tape recording sent to the Los Angeles Free Press.  The CLF stated that they were "fed up with our people being treated like dogs." However, authorities could not confirm if the CLF actually committed the attack.
scite1: "Bombing In LA," The Modesto Bee, May 9, 1971.

scite1: Unspecified

summary: None

summary: 5/9/1971: Suspected members of the Chicano Liberation Front tossed a firebomb into the Shopping Bag market in Altadena, California, United States. There were no casualties but the supermarket sustained an estimated $2,500 in damages.
motive: To protest the treatment of Mexican-Americans
addnotes: Most of the damage resulted from the automatic sprinklers putting out the flames.  The Chicano Liberation Front claimed credit for the incident in a tape recording sent to the Los Angeles Free Press.  The CLF stated that they were "fed up with our people being treated like dogs." However, authorities could not confirm if the CLF actually committed the attack.
scite1: "Market Bombing," The Modesto Bee, May 10, 1971.

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: 5/11/1971: In a series of two incidents that might have been part of a multiple attack, suspected members of the Chicano Liberation Front firebombed the Bank of America Woodland Hills branch in Los Angeles, California, United States. The bomb smashed through a window but did not cause any damage to the interior of the building.
target1: Bank of America, Woodland Hills branch in Los Angeles California
motive: Bank of America was perceived to symbolize the "capitalist exploitation of the little man."
weapdetail: Gallon jug containing flammable liquid smashed against the building
addnotes: This was part of a multiple attack with 197105110004.  Hours before the incident, the Glendale Savings and Loan in Los Angeles was bombed (197105110002).  The Chicano Liberation Front claimed credit for the incident in a tape recording sent to the Los Angeles Free Press.  The CLF stated that they were "fed up with our people being treated like dogs." However, authorities could not confirm if the CLF actually committed the attack.
scite1: "Probe Delays Mars Launch," Washington Post, May 12, 1971.

summary: 5/11/1971: In a series of two incidents that might have been part of a multiple attack, unknown perpetrators firebombed the Bank of America Chatworth branch in Los Angeles, California, United States. There were no casualties but the rear door of the building was damaged.
target1: Bank of America, Chatworth branch in Los Angeles California
motive: Bank of America was perceived to symbolize the "capitalist exploitation of the little man."
addnotes: This was part of a multiple attack with 197105110003.  Hours before the incident, the Glendale Savings and Loan in Los Angeles was bombed (197105110002).  The bomb extinguished itself before it caused any damage.
scite1: "Probe Delays Mars Launch," Washington Post, May 12, 1971.

summary: 5/11/1971: Unknown perpetrators firebombed Army Reserve Jeeps stationed at the Sheridan Armory in Baltimore, Maryland, United States. There were no casualties but three Jeeps sustained a total of $1,500 in damages. Nine other unexploded incendiary devices were discovered at the scene.
target1: Army Reserve Jeeps stationed at Sheridan Armory
motive: Protest and sabotage the US Army
weapdetail: Bottles of sulphuric acid leaked into the gas tanks of the Jeeps that ignited when it mixed with the gasoline
addnotes: The devices ignited around 4:00 AM.  The perpetrators scaled a barb-wire fence to enter the facility.  Nine months earlier, a firebomb was thrown at a truck stationed at a National Guard Armory in West Baltimore (197008220002).
scite1: "3 U.S. Jeeps Set A Fire At Armory," Baltimore Sun, May 12, 1971.

summary: 5/12/1971: Unknown perpetrators bombed the car of Lloyd Early, the Superintendent of Palm Beach County. The car was stationed in the parking lot of North Shore Junior-Senior High School in West Palm Beach, Florida, United States. The vehicle sustained minor damages. The Palm Beach County school district was the scene of intense racial conflict.
motive: African American opposition to the policies of the Palm Beach County school district
weapdetail: Bomb consisting of black powder, two batteries, and a clock
addnotes: The bomb detonated at 9:15 PM while the superintendent was attending a school board meeting.  Earlier in the day, there was a bomb threat at North Shore Junior-Senior High School.  There was also an attempted bombing of the car belonging to the principal of a West Palm Beach High School three months earlier (197102090002).
scite1: "Bomb Jolts Early's Car At School," The Palm Beach Post, May 13, 1971.

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: 5/19/1971: Members of the Black Liberation Army shot and wounded two police officers, Thomas P. Curry and Nicholas J. Binetti, in Manhattan, New York, United States. The officers were guarding the home of New York District Attorney Frank Hogan when they saw a car going the wrong way down a one-way street. When the officers caught up with the vehicle six blocks away, the perpetrators fired shots into the police car. The radio car was riddled with bullets and the windshield was shattered.
target1: Police officers guarding the home of New York District Attorney Frank Horgan
addnotes: The Black Liberation Army claimed the attack in letters to the New York Times and New York radio station WLIB.  The machine gun used in the incident was discovered by police while arresting members of the Black Liberation Army in a robbery two weeks later (197106050002).  Richard Moore (Dhoruba al-Mujahid Bin Walid) was convicted of the incident in 1973 after two previous trials went to hung juries.  However, the New York Supreme Court reversed the conviction in 1990 due to the prosecutions failure to disclose evidence to the defense.
scite1: Robert Daley, "Target Blue," Delacorte Press, 1973.

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: 5/21/1971: Two radical leftists failed in their attempts to firebomb the San Bruno Herald in San Bruno, California, United States.
motive: To communicate to the general public that 'political activities' are not just limited to extremist groups
addnotes: The message "Power to the people-print the truth" was taped to the door of the building.  In addition to George Patterson, an unnamed 17 year old male was also arrested.  Weeks earlier, the perpetrators attempted to firebomb a Bank of America branch in San Bruno (197105040005).  The perpetrators stated that they just wanted to get their message out and did not want to cause any damage.  They added that they did not belong to any 'fringe political group.'
scite1: "Tried to Communicate, Bombing Suspect Says," Los Angeles Times,, May 21, 1971.

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: None
scite1: Unspecified

summary: 5/28/1971: Unknown perpetrators placed a bomb in the parking lot of the Bedford Park Sherriff's Station in Bedford Park, Illinois, United States. The bomb was discovered and subsequently disarmed a half hour before it was supposed to detonate.
target1: Parking lot of Bedford Park Sherriff's Station
weapdetail: Five sticks of dynamite wired to an alarm clock placed in a suitcase
addnotes: The bomb was discovered and disarmed around 11:00 PM and was set detonate at 11:32 PM.
scite1: James Coates, "Bomb Set at Police Station," Chicago Tribune, May 29, 1971.

summary: 5/29/1971: Black militants fired into the Police Headquarters of Cairo, Illinois, United States, injuring a police officer. Following the shooting, police officers noticed four men armed with guns across the street from the station. The officers fired on the assailants initiating a shoot-out that lasted two hours. Two additional policemen sustained bullet wounds while all four perpetrators eventually escaped.
addnotes: The three injured policemen were Hershell Hoppe, Larry Modlin, and Terry Pigg.  The perpetrators were spotted near St. Columbia Church which had served as a headquarters for the Black United Front, an organization which was directing a boycott of White owned businesses in Cairo.
scite1: "3 Wounded in Cairo Shootout," Chicago Tribune, May 31, 1971.
